author: benjaminchodroff
content:
It took 83 epochs to change all 2133 validators using CLWP EIP-4736.

None of them were stolen by attackers.

The 10 validators that changed to a different address all belong to myselfâ€¦ because I hacked myself with grateful help from <@397389662085185547> who discovered an interesting libp2p attack. 

Congrats to everyone ðŸ¥³

author: schone_wizard

author: schone_wizard
content: thank you for your efforts and making this happen and pushing relentlessly for it, amazing job

author: schone_wizard
content: is there an opportunity to front run BLS change operations when they're stuck waiting? I seem to have a situation where one beacon node seems to show the operation in its queue while the other does not (missing validator indices)

author: pietjepuk
content: Not sure what you mean by front run, but you (or an adversary) can get a competing BLS change in a block yes.

author: schone_wizard
content: what happens to BLS changes that keep waiting seemingly forever?

author: schone_wizard
content: also what happens when such an attack occurs? does the beacon node with the still waiting operations simply discards them when it learns that those indices have had a change made to them in a block it just got from the network?

author: bridge-bot
content: <dannyryan> Not sure what you mean exactly but a bls change mempool should discard messages that can no longer be included on chain

author: bridge-bot
content: <dannyryan> So if there are two potential operations for a given index, then one will be included and the other discarded
